awd_titl_txt: Categories of Sheaves in Representation Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Representation theory is the study of symmetries in algebra. An understanding of symmetry allows us to reduce complicated problems to simpler ones.  Algebra can be used to describe a wide range of phenomena and structures throughout mathematics and the real world, and consequently representation theory has many important applications. Sheaves are geometric objects that generalize the usual notion of functions and have proven to be extremely effective in advancing our understanding of representation theory. This research project aims to uncover finer information about sheaves and applications of this information to representation theory.

Parity sheaves were introduced by the PI and his collaborators as a tool for studying the representation theory of reductive groups in positive characteristic.  The study of parity sheaves has also suggested the existence of new structures in categories of perverse sheaves.  The PI will explore these structures in some special, important, cases and their expected applications in a number of areas including the representations of Hecke algebras and modular representations of finite groups of Lie type. The geometric spaces to be studied are nilpotent cones and their generalizations for symmetric pairs and in gauge theory, as well as (generalized) flag varieties and toric varieties. The proposed methods include utilizing cohomological parity vanishing properties, nearby cycles and hyperbolic localization functors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Schur algebra, introduced by Isaii Schur in 1901, is an important mathematical object in the field of representation theory (the study of abstract symmetries).  Originally used to study the symmetries of finite sets and complex vector spaces, the Schur algebra has been used more recently to also study the representation theory of these objects over fields of positive characteristic and found to be related to the geometry of the nilpotent cone.  The nilpotent cone is the prototypical example of a family of geometric spaces called symplectic singularities.  The PI conjectured that one could find new, similarly important algebras by studying categories of perverse sheaves on other symplectic singularities.  Earlier he and Braden had discovered one class of examples - matroidal Schur algebras associated to hypertoric varieities.

A major outcome of this project was the discovery, joint with Tom Braden (UMass Amherst), of an enhancement of the Schur algebra - the Hilbert Schur algebra - associated to the symmetric products of the affine plane (or equivalently the space of configurations of n points in 2-dimensional complex space).

Also, together with Jens Eberhardt (University of Mainz), the PI developed a program for categorifying the matroidal Schur algebras.  As a step in this direction, the PI and his PhD student, Ethan Kowalenko, introduced a notion of category O associated to oriented matroid programs.

The Broader Impact of the work included training two PhD students (one graduated in 2021), two lecture series, numerous seminar, colloquium and conference talks and organizing conferences, including a workshop aimed at graduate students and postdocs and an international research conference with around 500 registered participants.
